H0.text: An oocyte is a mature egg that has finished meiosis twenty‑four hours before fertilization.

H1.text: Spermatozoa are the mature egg that has finished meiosis 24 hours before fertilization.

H2.text: Fetus is the mature form that the egg becomes twenty‑four hours before fertilization after it has finished meiosis.

H3.text: Zygote is the mature form of the egg twenty‑four hours before fertilization, after it has finished meiosis.

A4.text: The oocyte is arrested in Meiosis II at the stage of metaphase II and is considered a secondary oocyte.

A5.text: During fertilization, the sperm provides three essential parts to the oocyte: (1) a signalling or activating factor, which causes the metabolically dormant oocyte to activate; (2) the haploid paternal genome; (3) the centrosome, which is responsible for maintaining the microtubule system.

A6.text: Female mammals and birds are born possessing all the oocytes needed for future ovulations, and these oocytes are arrested at the prophase I stage of meiosis.

A7.text: The micrograph depicts a primary oocyte.

A8.text: This process is also halted at the metaphase II stage until fertilization.

A9.text: Meiosis I of ootidogenesis begins during embryonic development, but halts in the diplotene stage of prophase I until puberty.

A10.text: In meiosis II, division of the daughter cell produces a second polar body, and a single haploid cell, which enlarges to become an ovum.

A11.text: Therefore, in females each primary oocyte that undergoes meiosis results in one mature ovum and two or three polar bodies.

A12.text: The oocyte completes its second meiotic division, resulting in a mature haploid ovum and the release of a polar body.

A13.text: The result of this union leads to the production of a fertilized egg called a zygote, initiating embryonic development.
